docs.title: 1. Configure Virtual Environment and Install Django
docs.text:
1. Create Virtual Environment.

     python -m venv [env name].

  2. Update PIP

    python -m pip install --upgrade pip

  3. Activate venv.

    [env_name]\scripts\activate

  4. Install Django.

    python -m pip install django

  5. Start project to create framework/files.

    django-admin startproject [projectname] .

docs.title: 2. Build Database
docs.text: python manage.py migrate

docs.title: 3. Run the Web Server
docs.text: python manage.py runserver

docs.title: 4. Start the Web App
docs.text:
1. Open a new terminal (CTRL + SHIFT + `).
  2. Navigate to venv/directory with Manage.py.
  3. Activate venv.
  4. Navigate to project directory.
  5. Start the app to create the framework/files for the project.
    python manage.py startapp [app_name]

docs.title: 5. Creating Models
docs.text:
1. Define the model in models.py.
  2. Activate the model by adding the model to settings.py.

  3. Stage the model with makemigrations.

    python manage.py makemigrations

  4. Push the model to db with migrate.

    python manage.py migrate

  5. Register the model with admin site.

docs.title: 6. Establish Django Admin Site
docs.text:
1. Create Superuser.

    python manage.py createsuperuser

  2. Register models with admin site. admin.py

    from django.contrib import admin

# Register your models here.

from .models import Topic

admin.site.register(Topic)

docs.title: Build Templates
docs.text:
Templates are the overall structure of the page.

  1. Create a folder called templates inside project folder. [INITIAL]
  2. Create a nested folder called project_name.
  3. Add page_name.html that was used in views/urls files to templates/project_name directory.

docs.title: Base Templates
docs.text: Base templates contain repeated elements common to all pages called base.html and are placed in the templates/[app_name] directory.

docs.title: Template Tags
docs.text:
Template tags are indicated using curly braces and percentage signs to generate information to be displayed on a page.

    {% url 'learning_logs:index' %}

This code generates a URL matching the URL pattern defined in urls.py with name index.

docs.title: Block Tags
docs.text:
Reserves space for a child template to define content.

You can include as many blocks as needed. A child template does not need to utilize or fill every block to work.

    {% block content %}{% endblock content %}

docs.title: Child Templates
docs.text:
Child templates must start with extends 'app_name/base.html' to indicate the parent template to inherit from.

    {% extends 'learning_logs/base.html %}

    {% block content %}

    <p> Learning Log helps you keep track of your learning, for any topic you're interested in. </p>

    {% end block content %}

docs.title: Creating Child Templates
docs.text:
The URL pattern now contains the word topics in Views.py:

     # Topic Template
    path('topics/', views.topics, name='topics'),

The topics() function in view.py is updated to retrieve information from the database:

  1. Import the model associated with the data we need.
  2. The topics() function needs the parameter request object Django receives from the server.
  3. Query the database by asking for the Topic objects sorted by the date_added attribute.
  4. Define a context that is sent to the template. A Context is a dictionary in which keys are names used in the template to access data and values are data needed to be sent to the template.

When building a page that uses data retrieved from the database, you call the render() function with the request object, the template to use, and the context dictionary.

    1    def topics(request):
            """Show all topics"""
    2        topics = Topic.objects.order_by('date_added')
    3        context = {'topics': topics}
    4        return render(request, 'learning_logs/topics.html', context)

docs.title: Define URL Patterns
docs.text:
URL Patterns describe the way the URL is laid out and tells Django what to look for when matching a browser request.

Url pattern is a call to the path() function that takes 3 arguments:

urlpatterns = [
        # Homepage
        path('', views.index, name='index') ## List of individual pages in this app
    ]
  1. Base URL (empty string in the above example)
  2. Specifies which function to call in views.py
  3. Third specifies the name for the pattern for easy reference throughout the project.

docs.title: Initial Setup
docs.text:
1. Define URL Pattern - (urls.py) -

    1. Import include function by adding to django.urls in Project directory urls.py.

      Needed to map URLs to views

      from django.contrib import admin
from django.urls import path, include

    2. Include URL via path function in Project directory urls.py.

    The path function entered here is creating a direct link to the urls.py file that will be placed in the application directory.

        urlpatterns = [
    path('admin/', admin.site.urls),
    path('', include('learning_logs.urls')),
    ]
    1. Create a urls.py file in the app directory and include:

      The . in import views tells Django to import from same directory where this urls.py file lives. 

      """Defines URL patterns for learning_logs."""

from django.urls import path

from . import views

app_name = 'learning_logs'  ## distinguishes this urls.py from other apps in project

urlpatterns = [
    # Homepage
    path('', views.index, name='index') ## List of individual pages in this app
]

docs.title: Define Views
docs.text:
When a URL request matches a pattern defined in urls.py, Django looks in views.py for the corresponding function. In this example, views.index in urls.py looks for the index function in views.py.

Views function calls the render() function which passes 2 arguments:

  1. The original request object
  2. Template to use to build the page.

Write View - URLs map to Views which retrieve and process the data needed for the page. Views render templates. 1. Open views.py and add:

        from django.shortcuts import render

        def index(request):
        """The return homepage for Learning Log"""
        return render(request, 'learning_logs/index.html')

docs.title: Principles Used
docs.text:
• Template Tags generate information to be displayed on the page.
  • {% block [block_name] %}{endblock [block_name] %} indicates a code block to be filled by a child template.
  • For Loops Every 'for loop' in template code requires an endfor to end the loop.
  • To print a variable in a template wrap the variable name in double braces.
  • Template Filters are vertical lines used to call a function that modifies the value in a template variable during rendering.
  • {% empty %} Template Tags tell the interpreter what to do if the list is empty.
  • Django's Object-Relational Mapper (ORM) lets you interact with your database using Python objects instead of raw SQL queries. You define models (Python classes) that represent database tables. Django’s ORM automatically translates your Python code into SQL commands behind the scenes.

docs.title: URLs.py Example
docs.text:
1. Import Path function.
  2. Import views from same directory (.)
  3. Define application name
  4. Path function requires 3 parameters: URL that when matched calls the views thats defined and assigns it an arbitrary name.
    """Defines URL patterns for learning_logs."""

1    from django.urls import path

2    from . import views

3    app_name = 'learning_logs'

     urlpatterns = [
         # Homepage
         path('', views.index, name='index'),

         # Topic Template
         path('topics/', views.topics, name='topics'),

         # Detail page for a single topic
4        path('topics/<int:topic_id>/', views.topic, name='topic'),
        ]

docs.title: Views.py (Application) Example
docs.text:
1. Import render function from django.shortcuts.
  2. Import the Topic class object defined in models.py.
  3. Define the view function that requires the request parameter and an additional 'topic_id' parameter to be passed back to the View to be used in the path. Typically int:topic_id.

  4. Define the 'topic' variable that becomes a list of objects created using the Topic class. Uses the Get function or Django’s ORM to retrieve a single Topic object from the database whose primary key (id) matches the given topic_id.

  5. Defines the entries variables by creating a list of entries using entry_set. entry_set is the reverse relationship to Entry objects (assuming Entry has a ForeignKey to Topic) which gives all Entry objects linked to the current topic. .order_by('-date_added') sorts them by newest first (descending order).

  6. A context dictionary is created to pass data into the template with topic: the current topic object and entries: all the related entries for that topic.
  7. Renders the template learning_logs/topic.html with the given context. This produces an HTML page that displays the topic and its related entries.
1    from django.shortcuts import render

2    from .models import Topic

    def index(request):
        """The return homepage for Learning Log"""
        return render(request, 'learning_logs/index.html')

    def topics(request):
        """Show all topics"""
        topics = Topic.objects.order_by('date_added')
        context = {'topics': topics}
        return render(request, 'learning_logs/topics.html', context)

3    def topic(request, topic_id):
        """Show a single topic and all its entries"""
4        topic = Topic.objects.get(id = topic_id)
5        entries = topic.entry_set.order_by('-date_added')
6        context = {'topic': topic, 'entries' : entries}
7        return render(request, 'learning_logs/topic.html', context)

docs.title: Models.py Example
docs.text:
from django.db import models

        # Create your models here.

        class Topic(models.Model):
            """A topic the user is learning about."""
            text = models.CharField(max_length=200)
            date_added = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

            def __str__(self):
                """Returns a string representation of the model."""
                return self.text

        class Entry(models.Model):
            """Something specific learned about a topic."""
            topic = models.ForeignKey(Topic, on_delete=models.CASCADE)
            text = models.TextField()
            date_added = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

            class Meta:
                verbose_name_plural='entries'

            def __str__(self):
                if len(self.text) <= 50:
                    return self.text
                else:
                    return f"{self.text[:50]}..."

{% extends 'learning_logs/base.html' %}

    {% block content %}

    <p>Topics</p>

    <ul>
        {% for topic in topics %}
            <li><a href="{% url 'learning_logs:topic' topic.id %}">{{ topic.text }}</a></li>
        {% empty %}
            <li>No topics have been added yet.</li>
        {% endfor %}    
    </ul>

    {% endblock content %}

docs.title: Topic Example
docs.text:
{% extends 'learning_logs/base.html' %}

    {% block content %}

    <p>Topic: {{ topic.text }}</p>

    <p>
        Entries:
    </p>
    <ul>
        {% for entry in entries %}
        <li>
            <p>{{ entry.date_added|date:'M d, Y H:i' }}</p>
            <p>{{ entry.text | linebreaks }}</p>
        </li>
        {% empty %}
        <li>There are no entries for this topic yet. </li>
        {% endfor %}
    </ul>

    {% endblock content %}

docs.title: Defining Models
docs.text:
Models.py created during startapp. Models are classes with attributes and methods as expected.

  1. Define the model in models.py
  2. Add model to settings.py
  3. Stage the model with makemigrations
  4. Push the model to db with migrate
  5. Register the model with admin site.

docs.title: Django Model Attributes & Classes (Most Common First)
docs.text:
Field Types Description Example CharField Stores short text strings; requires max_length. name = models.CharField(max_length=100) TextField Stores long-form text; no length limit. description = models.TextField() IntegerField Stores integer values. age = models.IntegerField() DateTimeField Stores date and time; can auto-set on create/update. created_at = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True) BooleanField Stores True/False. is_active = models.BooleanField(default=True) DecimalField Fixed-point decimal number; requires max_digits and decimal_places. price = models.DecimalField(max_digits=6, decimal_places=2) FloatField Stores floating-point numbers. rating = models.FloatField() SlugField Stores URL-friendly text; often used for slugs. slug = models.SlugField(unique=True) EmailField Stores email addresses; validates format. email = models.EmailField() URLField Stores URLs; validates format. website = models.URLField() FileField Stores file uploads; requires upload_to path. file = models.FileField(upload_to='uploads/') ImageField Stores image uploads; requires Pillow. image = models.ImageField(upload_to='images/') UUIDField Stores universally unique identifiers. uuid = models.UUIDField(default=uuid.uuid4, editable=False) Relationship Fields Description Example ForeignKey Many-to-one relationship; links to another model. author = models.ForeignKey(User, on_delete=models.CASCADE) OneToOneField One-to-one relationship between models. profile = models.OneToOneField(User, on_delete=models.CASCADE) ManyToManyField Many-to-many relationship between models. tags = models.ManyToManyField(Tag) Field Options Description Example unique=True Ensures field values are unique in the database. email = models.EmailField(unique=True) blank=True Allows the field to be left blank in forms. middle_name = models.CharField(max_length=50, blank=True) null=True Allows storing NULL in the database. nickname = models.CharField(max_length=50, null=True) default Sets a default value for a field. is_active = models.BooleanField(default=True) choices Enum-like choices for a field. status = models.CharField(max_length=20, choices=STATUS_CHOICES) help_text Adds descriptive text for forms/admin. name = models.CharField(max_length=100, help_text="Full legal name") verbose_name Human-readable name for a field. email = models.EmailField(verbose_name="Email Address") db_index=True Adds a database index for faster lookups. created_at = models.DateTimeField(db_index=True) primary_key=True Marks the field as the primary key. id = models.AutoField(primary_key=True) Model Metadata Description Example Meta Inner class defining model options (ordering, verbose names). class Meta: ordering = ['-created_at']

ForeignKey(linked_model, on_delete=models.CASCADE) Database term for a reference to another record.

Many-to-one relationship is a model/object that is related to many others. For example, an entry object must be related to a particular topic/journal.

docs.title: Defining Models
docs.text:
It's a good idea to tell Django how you want it to represent an instance of a model. The str method tells Django to retrun the value assigned to the text attribute.

    class Topic(models.Model):
        """A topic the user is learning about."""
        text = models.CharField(max_length=200)
        date_added = models.DateTimeField(auto_now_add=True)

    def __str__(self):
        """Returns a string representation of the model."""
        return self.text

docs.title: Activating Models
docs.text:
You must tell Django to include our app in the overall project using settings.py.

Include your apps before the OOB Django apps in the case that your apps need to override some default Django functionality. 

    INSTALLED_APPS = [
    # My Apps
    'learning_logs',

    # OOB Django Apps
    'django.contrib.admin',
    'django.contrib.auth',
    'django.contrib.contenttypes',
    'django.contrib.sessions',
    'django.contrib.messages',
    'django.contrib.staticfiles',
    ]

docs.title: Make Migrations/Migrate DB
docs.text:
The makemigrations command essentially stages/commits the changes. Django figures out how it can modify the db to include the changes. 

    python manage.py makemigrations learning_logs

Next, we migrate to the db to push our changes.

    python manage.py migrate

docs.title: Problem
docs.text: Three different websites hosted under the same umbrella project. I am an Admin who wants to create an article for a specific site using the Django Admin Portal. I want to be able to select 'Create New Article' and create an article specific to the site.
